At my last contract job we did a major upgrade to the accounting system. I =
had unit tested any function (this was c++ code) that I touched and first-g=
eneration functions that I called. When it came time to go to integration t=
esting there was not one single integration test that my code did not pass.=
 Since the unit test already tested that I conformed to published API requi=
rements.

Given the fact that (at least at that job) unit testing involved =
only the programmer making the code changes - and integration testing invol=
ved the testers, all of the programmers - project leaders - and finally dep=
artment managers. Every failed integration test was very expensive.
	Failed=
 integration tests were even more expensive since half the department were =
hourly contractors and testers worked second shift. So, all failed tests as=
 time was running out involved bringing multiple programmers back into work=
 to fix the problem (which caused regressing testing on any other integrati=
on tests the code might touch). Small, early, and very localized testing wi=
ll remove the large number of regression tests that must be run.

Now, if o=
nly I can get my current employer to work with unit testing, heck at this p=
oint I would just like to get a design documents rather than the "task of t=
he day", reboot everything type of system we survive under now. Once I get =
that I can talk to them about the need for source control.


Chip

Mike,

I think that they're both valuable (and nece=
ssary), mostly because they
test different things.

My unit tests guarantee=
 that the small parts of my code work the way I
expect them to, and enforce=
 the contracts of the API I'm providing.  I
can test code that interacts wi=
th other systems even before those other
systems exist, so long as we've de=
fined their API.  Its important,
however, to limit the scope of your unit t=
ests to things that *you* are
responsible for.  If you miss that, you'll en=
d up writing
unit-integration tests, that I find become unwieldy fairly qui=
ckly.

What I've noticed in my integration testing is that now that I use u=
nit
tests, finding the actual problems that crop up during integration
test=
ing takes much less time.  Whereas before all I knew was "the
webpage does =
NOT appear" and I had a forest of reasons why that could
be, now I know fro=
m my unit tests that large parts of the system are
working, and the problem=
 must be somewhere in the 'seams'.

Actually, I'd say that leads me to the =
opposite of your hunch that "the
cost-per-bug-eliminated of unit testing is=
 higher than that of
integration testing", because there's generally a long=
 period of time
in the integration test between bug discovery and bug repai=
r, where in
my unit tests, its quite small.  I suppose I'd also disagree th=
at the
two take the same amount of time to construct, as I'm a true believe=
r
(tm) that writing unit tests at the same time as your code takes the
same=
 time as writing your code without unit tests and testing by hand. 
In both=
 those cases you still have to go through integration tests when
you're don=
e.

Lastly, the advantages in cleanup of your API (if it isn't easlity
test=
able, it may not be easily usable) are, to me at least, very real
and signi=
ficant.

Just to be clear, I still integration test, too.  It just tends to=
 go
smoother, and I have better knowledge of where the problem is.

This ob=
viously wasn't a scientific study paper, but hopefully its a
helpful perspe=
ctive.

Kevin
